name: 3-amino-1-(4-chlorophenyl)-1h-pyrazole
Reason: 1-phenyl-3-amino-1H-pyrazole has a melting point that we can compare to the base of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The introduction of a 4-chlorophenyl group increases the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces. The chlorine atom also increases the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the ability to form hydrogen bonds. The amino group introduces additional hydrogen bonding potential, which can lower the melting point. The phenyl group also increases the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces. The net effect is a complex interplay of increases and decreases.
